title: Electric potential -calculate V from point charges

content.description: A uniformly charged nonconducting sphere of radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> with positive net charge <math alttext="positive Q" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></math> is fixed in place with its center along the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-axis, as shown. The bottom edge of the sphere is a distance <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> from the origin. A point charge with negative charge <math alttext="negative Q" overflow="scroll"> <mo>-</mo> <mi>Q</mi> </math> is placed on the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis a distance <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> from the origin.
content.question: If <math alttext="R equals 25 centimeters" overflow="scroll"> <mi>R</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>25</mn> <mspace width="0.2em"> </mspace> <mtext>cm</mtext> </math> and <math alttext="Q equals 30 nanocoulombs" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>nC</mtext></math>, what is the approximate electric potential at the origin?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
